questions.text: A 78-year-old woman with hypertension presents with a weakness of left upper and lower limbs suggestive of hemiparesis. Cardiac monitoring reveals the finding as shown in the figure. Heart rate is 160/min, irregular. BP is 130/80.Lungs are clear on auscultation. Along with rate control, which of the following is appropriate management?

options.label: D
options.text: Warfarin with a target INR of 2.0 to 3.0

questions.correct_answer: D. Warfarin with a target INR of 2.0 to 3.0

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the ER with lethargy and blood pressure of 250/150. and complaining of severe headache and visual disturbance. She has history of uncontrolled bronchial asthma. On physical examination, retinal hemorrhages are present. Neurological examination reveals no focal weakness. Serum creatinine is normal. Which of the following is the best approach?

A 21-year-old man dies suddenly during his track workout. The man had a history of occasional fainting, as does his brother. On autopsy, his heart showed a hypertrophy interventricular septum out of proportion with the rest of the heart. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

26-year-old woman presents 12 weeks post-partum with symptoms of weight loss, palpitations and tremor. Her thyroid function is checked, revealing high free T4 and free T3 with TSH <0.01mIU/L. TSH receptor antibody levels are not elevated. What is the most appropriate management?

A 54-year-old man is admitted to the medical intensive care unit with sepsis associated with pneumococcal pneumonia. He requires mechanical ventilation as well as norepinephrine to maintain a mean arterial pressure >60 mmHg. Invasive hemodynamic show adequate left heart filing pressures, and he is not known to have left ventricular dysfunction. On the third hospital day, his urine output drops and creatinine increases to 3.4 mg/dL. Acute tubular injury is diagnosed. Which of the following agents has been shown to improve outcomes associated with his acute tubular injury?

A 110-kg 57-year-old man presents with 1-month history of lethargy, increased urinary frequency, weight loss and increased thirst. On examination BP is 150/100 mmHg, acanthosis nigricans present on back of the neck. What would be the simplest test that could make the diagnosis?
A COPD patient non- compliant with his medications presented to ER with palpitations and dyspnea. ECG done is shown in the figure. What is the cause of these symptoms?

A 70-year-old nursing home resident is admitted to the hospital for pneumonia and treated for 10 days with levofloxacin. She improves but develops diarrhea 1 week after discharge, with low-grade fever, mild abdominal pain, and 2 to 3 watery, non-bloody stools per day. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for Clostridium difficile toxin in a stool sample is positive. The patient is treated with oral metronidazole, but does not improve after 10 days. Diarrhea has increased and fever and abdominal pain continue. What is the best next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Continue metronidazole for at least 2 more weeks.

options.label: C
options.text: Hospitalize patient for fulminant C difficile–associated disease.

questions.correct_answer: B. Switch treatment to oral vancomycin.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman complains of dry mouth and a gritty sensation in her eyes. She states it is sometimes difficult to speak for more than a few minutes. There is no history of diabetes mellitus or neurologic disease. The patient is on no medications. On examination, the buccal mucosa appears dry and the salivary glands are enlarged bilaterally. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of the condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Previous exposure to group A streptococcal organisms have stimulated an autoimmune response that leads to cross-reactivity between host and organism with tissue destruction and reduced tear and saliva production.

options.label: C
options.text: Activated T cells and monocytes accumulate in the skin leading to induration

options.label: D
options.text: Immune complexes form and deposit in vessel walls

questions.correct_answer: B. T cells infiltrate exocrine glands

questions.text: A 75-year-old man complains of headache which increased on lying down. He also c/o pain in the shoulders and neck, particularly in the morning. There are no focal neurologic findings. Carotid pulses are normal without bruits. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 85. There is past history of transient loss of vision. Which of the following is the best approach to management?

options.label: A
options.text: Begin glucocorticoid therapy and arrange for temporal artery biopsy.

options.label: B
options.text: Temporal artery biopsy and begin corticosteroids based on biopsy results and clinical course.

options.label: D
options.text: Follow ESR and consider further studies if it remains elevated.

questions.correct_answer: A. Begin glucocorticoid therapy and arrange for temporal artery biopsy.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman presents with pain in the fingers bilaterally. Examination reveals inflammation of distal inter-phalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints. Larger joints are spared. Skin examination reveals this lesion (see figure). What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old alcoholic develops cough and fever. Sputum is foul smelling and examination reveals wet crepts in the right base. Chest x-ray, shown below, shows an air-fluid level in the superior segment of the right lower lobe. Which of the following is the most likely etiologic agent?
A patient presented with sudden onset left-sided pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea. Chest x-ray is done as shown in the figure. Which of the clinical sign will not be seen?

A 35-year-old woman with hypertensive kidney disease progresses to end-stage renal disease. She was initiated on peritoneal dialysis 1 year ago and has done well with relief of her uremic symptoms. She is brought to the emergency department with fever, altered mental status, diffuse abdominal pain, and cloudy dialysate. Her peritoneal fluid is withdrawn through her catheter and sent to the laboratory for analysis. The fluid white blood cell count is 125/μL with 85% polymorphonuclear neutrophils. Which organism is most likely to be found on culture of the peritoneal fluid?

A 78-year-old man with a history of prostate cancer presents to the emergency department with weakness affecting his right arm and leg and left face. The weakness began abruptly earlier during the day and is associated with numbness and paresthesias. On physical examination, strength is 4/5 in the right leg and arm. The upper and lower facial muscles fail to move on the left. Babinski sign is positive. Sensation is decreased in the right extremities and on the left face. Based on this information, what is the most likely site of the lesion causing the patient’s symptoms?

A 34-year-old woman seeks evaluation for weakness. She has noted tripping when walking, particularly in her left foot, for the past 2 years. She also has recently begun to drop things, once allowing a full cup of coffee to spill onto her legs. The patient also feels as if the appearance of her face has changed over the course of many years, stating that she feels as if her face is becoming hollower and more elongated although she hasn’t lost any weight recently. She has not seen a physician in many years and has no past medical history. Her only medications are a multivitamin and calcium with vitamin D. Her family history is significant for similar symptoms of weakness in her brother who is 2 years older. Her mother, who is 58 years old, was diagnosed with mild weakness after her brother was evaluated but is not symptomatic. On physical examination, the patient’s face appears long and narrow with wasting of the temporalis and masseter muscles. Her speech is mildly dysarthric, and the palate is high and arched. Strength is 4/5 in the intrinsic muscles of the hand, wrist extensors, and ankle dorsiflexors. After testing handgrip strength, you notice that there is a delayed relaxation of the muscles of the hand. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 22-year-old woman who is otherwise healthy undergoes an uneventful vaginal delivery of a fullterm infant. One day postpartum, she complains of visual changes and severe headache. Two hours after these complaints, she is found unresponsive and profoundly hypotensive. She is intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. Her blood pressure is 68/28 mmHg, regular heart rate is 148 bpm, her oxygen saturation is 95% on fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 0.40. Physical exam is unremarkable. Her laboratory tests are notable for glucose of 49 mg/dL, with normal hematocrit and white blood cell count. Which of the following is most likely to reverse her hypotension?

options.label: A
options.text: Transfusion of packed red blood cells

questions.text: An 87-year-old woman is admitted to the intensive care unit with depressed level of consciousness, hypothermia (body temperature 33 C), sinus bradycardia, hypotension, and hypoglycemia. She was previously healthy with the exception of hypothyroidism and systemic hypertension. Her family recently checked in on her and found that she was not taking any of her medications because of financial difficulties. There is no evidence of infection on exam, urine microscopy, or chest radiograph. Her serum chemistries are notable for mild hyponatremia and a glucose of 48 mg/dL. and TSH is >100 mU/L. All of the following statements regarding this condition are true EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: External warming is important feature of therapy

questions.correct_answer: A. External warming is important feature of therapy

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit with fulminant hepatic failure and hemolysis. On further questioning, his family reports that he has been diagnosed with depression for 5 years and had a prior episode of acute hepatitis 2 years ago that resolved. At that time, his aspartate aminotransferase peaked at 1200 U/L and alanine aminotransferase peaked at 1900 U/L, with a total bilirubin of 7.2 g/dL. No cause of the hepatitis was found despite a workup that included viral and autoimmune causes. His liver function returned to normal. He is taking an antidepressant and occasional ibuprofen, but no other medications. Physical examination is notable for ascites and altered mental status with dystonia. Abdominal CT scan shows no biliary obstruction but a cirrhotic liver. Which of the following findings would be most likely to confirm the underlying diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Slit-lamp ocular examination showing Kayser-Fleischer rings

options.label: B
options.text: Brain MRI showing damage to the basal ganglia

options.label: D
options.text: Schistocytes on peripheral blood smear E.

questions.correct_answer: A. Slit-lamp ocular examination showing Kayser-Fleischer rings

questions.text: A 47-year-old man is seen for an annual examination. He generally has no complaints but lives a sedentary lifestyle. He works as an accountant and spends of his work days at a computer screen. He does not maintain a regular exercise routine. He admits his diet is poor. He is divorced and lives alone. He eats out or gets take out about 4 nights a week. On other days, he prefers quick meals that he can heat up in the microwave. His past medical history is significant for hypertension and obesity. He is being treated with hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily. He has no allergies. His blood pressure today is 148/92 mmHg. His waist circumference is 110 cm. He is 177.8 cm tall and weighs 105 kg. His BMI is 32.3 kg/m2. On his blood reports, his total cholesterol is 220 mg/dL, HDL is 28 mg/dL, triglycerides are 178 mg/dL, and LDL is 103 mg/dL. Fasting plasma glucose is 98 mg/dL. Which of the following is true regarding a diagnosis of metabolic syndrome in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: He cannot have metabolic syndrome because his fasting plasma glucose level is normal.

options.label: B
options.text: He has metabolic syndrome because he meets three out of five diagnostic criteria: high triglyceride levels, low HDL level, and hypertension.

options.label: C
options.text: He has metabolic syndrome because he meets four out of five diagnostic criteria: high BMI, high triglyceride levels, low HDL level, and hypertension.

options.label: D
options.text: He has metabolic syndrome because he meets four out of five diagnostic criteria: large waist circumference, high triglyceride levels, low HDL level, and hypertension.

questions.correct_answer: D. He has metabolic syndrome because he meets four out of five diagnostic criteria: large waist circumference, high triglyceride levels, low HDL level, and hypertension.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with chronic obstructive lung disease requires 2 L/min of nasal O2 to treat his hypoxia, which is sometimes associated with angina. The patient develops pleuritic chest pain, fever, and purulent sputum. While using his oxygen at an increased flow of 5 L/min, he becomes stuporous and develops a respiratory acidosis with CO2 retention and worsening hypoxia. What would be the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Treat with antibiotics and observe on the general medicine ward for 24 hours

questions.correct_answer: C. Intubate and begin mechanical ventilation

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of infertility. He has a lifelong history of a productive cough and recurrent pulmonary infections. On his review of symptoms, he has indicated chronic problems with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and difficulty gaining weight. He also has diabetes mellitus. His chest x-ray suggests bronchiectasis. Which is the most likely diagnosis?

A 62-year-old automobile service worker presents with gradually worsening exertional dyspnea over the preceding several months. Recently, he has noticed right pleuritic chest pain. He has hypertension, well controlled on amlodipine 5 mg/d. He takes no other medications. He has never noticed cough or wheezing while at work. He worked for 15 years in construction and demolition and for 20 years thereafter in the service department of an automotive dealership. He denies fever, chills, or night sweats. On physical examination, he is in no respiratory distress but has right basilar dullness. His finger oximetry reads 96% on room air. Chest x-ray reveals a moderate right pleural effusion and lateral pleural thickening on both sides. Thoracentesis shows reddish fluid, which on formal analysis is an exudate with 45,000 RBCs/hpf. Cytology is negative. What is the most likely explanation for this patient’s symptoms?

options.label: C
options.text: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis due to thermophilic actinomycetes

questions.text: An obese 50-year-old woman complains of insomnia, daytime sleepiness, and fatigue. During a sleep study she is found to have recurrent episodes of arterial desaturation—about 30 events per hour —with evidence of obstructive apnea. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.correct_answer: A. Nasal continuous positive airway pressure

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with gradually worsening dyspnea over the preceding 6 months. She has a mild non-productive cough. She previously had been diagnosed with systemic sclerosis. For her Raynaud syndrome, she is taking amlodipine. She has no renal disease or hypertension. On physical examination, her respiratory rate is 22/min and resting O2 saturation is 92%. She has thickened skin on the face, torso, and abdomen. Lung examination shows rales in the bases bilaterally. Neck veins are flat. Cardiac examination is normal with normal P2 and no heave. Chest x-ray shows increased interstitial lung markings and a normal heart size. What is the most important next step in evaluating this patient’s dyspnea?

options.label: C
options.text: Measurement of autoantibodies including anti-topoisomerase-1 (anti-Scl-70) antibodies

questions.correct_answer: D. High-resolution CT scan (HRCT) of chest

questions.text: A 66-year-old man sees you in clinic with a 3-month history of episodes of redness of the face and neck associated with a feeling of warmth. These episodes generally last less than 5 minutes and are often associated with watery diarrhea. Over the same period of time he has had episodic cramping abdominal pain and fatigue. His examination is remarkable for a systolic murmur heard at the left lower parasternal area; the murmur increases with inspiration. Which of the following test is most likely to result in the correct diagnosis?

A 56-year-old chronic alcohol intake is admitted with a 2-day history of diffuse abdominal pain and fever. Examination reveals scleral icterus, spider angiomas, a distended abdomen with shifting dullness, and diffuse abdominal tenderness. Paracentesis reveals slightly cloudy ascitic fluid with an ascitic fluid PMN cell count of 1000/μL, protein 0.9 g/dl and culture growing E Coli. What will be the next line of management?

A 31-year-old football player with a head injury is brought to a local emergency department. Physical examination, radiogram, and a magnetic resonance imaging scan indicate a lesion of the trigeminal nerve. Which of the following muscles is most likely paralyzed?

A 41-year-old woman overdoses on some prescription medications that have a common side effect of autonomic nerve stimulation. Which of the following conditions or actions results from stimulation of the parasympathetic fibers to the eyeball?

options.label: C
options.text: Contraction of capillaries in the iris

questions.correct_answer: D. Contraction of the ciliary muscle

questions.text: A high school basketball player experiences a sudden difficulty in breathing and is brought to an emergency department. When a low tracheotomy is performed below the isthmus of the thyroid, which of the following vessels may be encountered?
A 27-year-old patient with Marfan syndrome has an aneurysm of the aortic arch. This may compress which of the following structures?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Sol:
  • ↳ The left recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the arch of the aorta near the ligamentum arteriosum, whereas the right recurrent
  • ↳ laryngeal nerve hooks around the right subclavian artery. All other nerves are not closely associated with the aortic arch.

questions.text: A mother with diabetes gives birth to a baby who is diagnosed as having dextroposition of the aorta and the pulmonary trunk with cyanosis and shortness of breath. Which of the following structure& la required to remain patent until surgical correction of the deformity?

A benign tumor in the orbit of a 49-year-old man compresses a structure that runs through both the superior orbital fissure and the common tendinous ring. Which of the following structures is most likely damaged?
At the onset of exercise, the mass sympathetic system strongly discharges. Which of the following would you expect to occur?
A 65-year-old patient with a heart murmur has a mean QRS axis of +120 degrees and the QRS complex lasts 0.18 seconds. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old patient with hypertension is well controlled with thiazide diuretics. At his last visit 6 months ago, his bp was 130/80 mm Hg and his serum creatinine was 1mg/100mL. he has been exercising regularly for the past two years but has reported knee pain for which he has been taking large amounts of NSAIDs. On his latest visit, his bp is 160/90 mm Hg and his serum creatinine is 2.5 mg/100mL. Which of the following is the best explanation for the increased serum creatinine?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased efferent arteriolar resistance that decreased GFR

options.label: B
options.text: Increased afferent arteriolar resistance that decreased GFR

options.label: C
options.text: Increased glomerular capillary ultrafiltration constant that decreased GFR

options.label: D
options.text: Increased angiotensin II that decreased GFR

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased afferent arteriolar resistance that decreased GFR

questions.text: A 35-year-old soldier sustains a bullet wound in the right side of the chest that causes a pneumothorax. Which of the following best describes the changes in his lung volume and thoracic volume as compared to a normal adult male?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased lung volume, increased thoracic volume

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased lung volume, decreased thoracic volume

options.label: C
options.text: Increased lung volume, decreased thoracic volume

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased lung volume, increased thoracic volume

questions.correct_answer: D. Decreased lung volume, increased thoracic volume

questions.text: A 19-year-old man suffered a severe road traffic accident and has been fed intravenously for several weeks. The intravenous feeding leads to atrophy of the gastrointestinal mucosa. The atrophy is most likely due to decreased blood level of which of the following gastrointestinal hormones?

A 30-year-old woman reports for an antenatal examination. Her thyroid profile shows that her plasma TSH is high, but her total thyroid hormone concentration is normal. Which of the following best reflects the patient’s clinical state?
A 5-years-old boy has temporary weakness and cramping of skeletal muscle after exercise. He has normal mental development. This child moist likely has a deficiency of which of the following enzymes?

A 7-years-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents with a complaint of severe polyuria and polydipsia. Laboratory examination reveals ketones in her urine. Which of the following is the most likely source of the ketones?

A 50-years old chronic alcohol presents with dementia, paralysis of lateral gaze, and difficulty walking. The vitamin deficient in this patient is required as a cofactor for which of the following enzymes?

25 year old lady coming with complain of easy tiredness and difficulty in doing house hold chores for past 4 months. She is strict vegetarian. On examination she is anaemic. Urine showed the presence of FIGLU [Formimino glutamic acid]. Peripheral smear show megaloblastic picture with hyper segmented nuclei. Which of the following enzyme activity will be affected in this patient?

A seven year old healthy child is presenting in OPD for routine check ups. His blood sugar is normal but urine shows positive benedicts test. This test is more strongly positive after consumption of fruit juice. Which of the following enzyme deficiency this child may be suffering with?

A 44-year-old man in acute distress is noted to have multiple ecchymoses of the skin that have developed over the past 48 hours. His prothrombin time (PT) is 38 seconds and partial thromboplastin time (PTT) 55 seconds. A CBC shows a WBC count of 5300/microliter, hemoglobin 8.1 g/dL, hematocrit 24.9%, MCV 99 fL, and platelet count 16,300/microliter. Which of the following tests holds significance in diagnosing this man’s condition?

A genetic counselor elicits the history that three adult males and one adult female in a family of 10 over 3 generations have an intellectual disability, the males more severely so. Physical examination of these affected males reveals no major morphologic anomalies, though their testes appear to be slightly enlarged, without mass lesions present. These males have been healthy, without a history of major illnesses. Which of the following genetic abnormalities is the most likely etiology for these findings?

A patient is admitted in emergency room with history suggestive of perforation peritonitis. Physical examination shows multiple ecchymotic patches in the skin. The intensivist is suspicious of a sepsis complicated by DIC and asks intern to draw the blood for culture, coagulation profile, platelet count, blood grouping and cross matching in further management of this patient, which is the correct order of drawing the tubes for the above mentioned tests?
questions.correct_answer: C. Culture tubes> Blue> Red> Levander

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman has had increasing numbers of pinpoint hemorrhages on her skin for the past few months. She has been treated with multiple random donor platelet transfusions before. On physical examination she is afebrile and normotensive. She has petechiae of skin and mucosal surfaces. Laboratory studies shown her platelet count is 10,000/microliter. She receives 5 units of random donor platelets. Following the transfusion, the platelet count is only 8,000/microliter. Which of the following is the most probable cause for this finding?

A 49 year old woman feels a lump in her left breast while taking a shower and visits the surgeon. On examination surgeon palpates a 2x2 cm hard mass deep in the left outer quadrant. Examination of axilla doesn’t show any palpable lymphnodes. A biopsy from the breast lesion showed an infiltrating duct carcinoma. Immunohistochemistry shows the tumor cells are negative for ER and PR but 3+ positive for Her2 Neu. Which of the following would have been the likely pathogenesis of such a tumor?

options.label: A
options.text: Gain of function mutation of a growth factor receptor

options.label: B
options.text: A gain of function mutation of growth factor

options.label: C
options.text: A loss of function mutation of tumor suppressor gene

questions.correct_answer: A. Gain of function mutation of a growth factor receptor

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman has noted dull pelvic pain for the last two months. On physical examination there is a mass palpated in the right lower quadrant. An abdominal ultrasound reveals an 8 cm mass involving the right ovary. The mass is surgically excised. On gross inspection, the surface of the mass is smooth and is not adherent to surrounding pelvic structure. On sectioning it is cystic and filled with hair. On microscopic examination there is squamous epithelium, tall columnar glandular epithelium, cartilage, and fibrous connective tissue. Which of the following neoplasms is she most likely to have?

A 15-year-old healthy girl with no major medical problems notes blotchy areas of erythema that are pruritic over the skin of her arms, legs, and trunk within an hour every time she eats seafood, followed by diarrhea. These problems abate within 3 hours, and then physical examination reveals no abnormal findings. Which of the following cell would have elicited such a reaction?
questions.correct_answer: C. IL-5, IL-13 secreting CD4+ cells

questions.text: A 5 year child presents with bleeding per rectum. Colonoscopy shows a polyp in the rectum. Histological examination is as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 21-year young adult presents with dark coloured urine after a respiratory tract infection. He had 5 such episodes in the last 3 years. urine examination shows 0-1 RBC per HPF, no Casts, a test for haemoglobin confirms presence of it in urine. Periphereal blood examination showed abnormal morphology in the RBC. The patients maternal uncle also has similar manifestation. Which of the following is most likely pathogenesis of such a manifestation?

options.label: B
options.text: Immune complex of IgA deposited in kidney

options.label: D
options.text: A type II hypersensitivity after viral infection.

questions.text: A 34 year male presents with recurrent infections and easy fatigue. Peripheral blood examination shows a TLC of 38,000 and differential count shows 18% blasts. A bone marrow examination shows 22% blasts with abundant granular cytoplasm and prominent nucleoli. Cytogenetic examination of the blasts shows FLT 3 mutation. Which of the following drug should be included in mutation specific treatment of this patient?

A 28 year lady presents with sudden onset of severe chest pain and breathlessness after undergoing an elective appendicectomy. Her BP is 100/80, respiratory rate is 30/min, O2 saturation is 89%. Although she didn’t have any bleeding disorders at the time of surgery her aPTT was 55 S (control 40 S), she was transfused with 1 unit of FFP and posted to emergency appendicectomy. There is no history of any other disease in her or any other family member having a similar diease. Intra operative events were uneventful and the surgeon was able to remove the inflamed but not ruptured appendix. The post-operative coagulation profile shows PT 15 s (control 15 S), aPTT 50 S (control 40 S). which of the following should not be included in the management of this patient?

A 44 year old man has developed an anaphylactic shock after getting blood transfusion. He had similar history of anaphylaxis to blood products 6 month back. On detailed he suggests that he gets allergic reaction to multiple things which his peers normally don’t get allergic to like eggs, medicines and some gluten containing food. He also says since childhood he falls sick more frequently usually flu like illness and also has had multiple episodes of mild diarrhoea. CBC shows Hb 11, TLC 10000/cu.mm, DLC N-70, L-20, Eo-7, Baso-2, others rest. Platelet count is 1.2Lakhs/cu.mm. The physician starts suspecting an inherited disorder in this patient, which of the following is pathogenesis in this patients disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Defective migration of stem cells into bone marrow.

options.label: D
options.text: A DNA repair defect leading to this.

questions.text: A 39 year lady presents with weight loss of 8 kg over last 2 months although she admits of not doing any extra mile with respect to her daily exercise. Clinical examination shows a cervical lymphnode is palpable. Chest X ray suggest lesions in the lungs and a few enlarged lymphnodes. Peripheral blood examination shows an elevated calcium. A biopsy from lung lesion and the cervical lymphnode was performed and showed similar lesions as shown in the image. Which of the following is most likely diagnosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Metastatic giant cell tumor of bone

questions.text: A 25-year-old man fell down from his bicycle and hit a concrete wall on his left side. An ultrasound examination showed free fluid in the abdomen. A CT scan confirmed a grade III splenic injury. The most important contraindication for a nonoperative management of the splenic injury is:

options.label: D
options.text: Lack of availability of blood for transfusion

questions.text: A 62-year-old man has had back pain for the past 8 months. He has had a productive cough for the past 2 days. On physical examination his temperature is 39°C and there is dullness to percussion at the right lung base. Laboratory studies show 4+ gram-positive diplococci in the sputum. A chest radiograph shows right lower lobe consolidation. An abdominal CT scan shows multiple lytic lesions of the vertebrae. On the day prior to death his serum urea nitrogen was 63 mg/dL with creatinine 7.1 mg/dL. A dipstick urinalysis was normal. At autopsy, his kidneys are firm and pale. Microscopic examination is as shown in the image. Which of the following laboratory findings would have been in this patient’s blood before death?

A 60-year-old man is attacked with a baseball bat and sustains multiple blows to the abdomen. He presents to the emergency department in shock and is brought to the operating room (OR), where a laparotomy reveals massive hemoperitoneum and a stellate fracture of the right and left lobes of the liver. Which of the following techniques should be used immediately?

options.label: D
options.text: Ligation of the right hepatic artery

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman has noted a small amount of irregular vaginal bleeding for the past 2 months. She has a pelvic examination that reveals no cervical lesions, and a Pap smear that shows no abnormal cells. Next, an endometrial biopsy is performed, and there is microscopic evidence for endometrial hyperplasia. An abdominal ultrasound reveals a solid right ovarian mass. Histological examination of this mass is likely to show which of the following features?

options.label: A
options.text: Hair follicles, cartilage, bone thyroid tissue.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male develops a cough that produces blood-tinged spu- tum. He has a fever of 104°F. Gram-positive cocci in clusters are found in a sputum smear. A chest x-ray shows increased density in the right upper lobe. Of the following penicillins, which is most likely to be ineffective?
Identify the knot shown in the image:

A 32-year-old cancer patient, who has smoked two packs of ciga- rettes a day for 10 years, presents a decreased pulmonary function test. Physical examination and chest x-rays suggest preexisting pulmonary dis- ease. Of the following drugs, which is best not prescribed?

Steering wheel injury on chest of a young man reveals multiple fractures of ribs and paradoxical movement with severe respiratory distress. X-ray shows pulmonary contusion on right side without pneumothorax or haemotho-rax. What is the treatment of choice?

options.label: C
options.text: Thoracic epidural analgesia and O2 therapy

questions.correct_answer: B. Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation

questions.text: A 64-year-old male with arteriosclerotic heart disease (AHD) and CHF who has been treated with digoxin complains of nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. His EKG reveals a bigeminal rhythm. The symptoms and EKG findings occurred shortly after another therapeutic agent was added to his regimen. A drug-drug interaction is suspected. Which agent was involved?

A 36-year-old male heroin addict is seen in the ED because he can- not be aroused from sleep. On examination, he has shallow breathing and pinpoint pupils. Naloxone is administered, and the patient wakes up. Which of the opiate receptor subtypes that binds naloxone is responsible for reversing the respiratory depression and miosis?

A 26-year-old woman presents with a palpable thyroid nodule shown in the image and needle biopsy demonstrates amyloid in palpable lymph nodes on the same side as the lesion. The preferred treatment should be:

options.label: A
options.text: Removal of the involved node, the isthmus, and the enlarged lymph node

options.label: B
options.text: Removal of the involved lobe, the isthmus, a portion of the opposite lobe, and the enlarged lymph node

options.label: C
options.text: Total thyroidectomy and modified neck dissection on the side of the enlarged lymph node

options.label: D
options.text: Total thyroidectomy and irradiation of the cervical lymph nodes

questions.correct_answer: C. Total thyroidectomy and modified neck dissection on the side of the enlarged lymph node

questions.text: A patient exhibiting multiple facial tics, aggressive outbursts of behav- ior, and spontaneous repetitive foul language is best treated with which of the following agents?

A male patient is brought to the emergency department (ED) follow- ing ingestion of an unknown substance. He is found to have an elevated temperature, hot and flushed skin, dilated pupils, and tachycardia. Of the following, which would most likely cause these findings?
A 74-year-old female has had several episodes of transient ischemic attacks (TIAs). She cannot tolerate aspirin. Which of the following should be considered as an alternative therapy?

A 56-year-old man undergoes coronary bypass surgery. He receives cefazolin prophylactically and at a dosage that is continued for 2 days postoperatively. On the 10th postoperative day, he develops a fever of 40°C with a heart rate of 110 beats per minute (bpm) and a blood pressure of 100/70 mm Hg. His white blood cell (WBC) count is 14.000 and a urinalysis reveals many white blood cells per high power held. Cultures of blood, urine, and the surgical wound are then obtained. The urine and wound cultures are positive with gram-negative rods. The organism is oxidase-positive and unable to ferment glucose. Large, spreading, beta-hemolytic colonies are seen on sheep blood agar, and colorless colonies are noted on MacConkey agar. Antimicrobial susceptibility testing reveals the organism is susceptible to imipenem and piperacillin-tazobactam. but it is resistant to trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole. 45-year-old gentleman has undergone truncalvagotomy and pyloroplasty for bleeding duodenal ulcer seven years ago. Now he was having intractable recurrent symptoms of peptic ulcer. All of the following suggest the diagnosis of Zollinger Ellison syndrome, except:

options.label: C
options.text: Ulcers in proximal jejunum and lower end of esophagus

options.label: D
options.text: Serum gastrin value of 200 pg/ml with secretin stimulation

questions.correct_answer: D. Serum gastrin value of 200 pg/ml with secretin stimulation
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Sol:
  • ↳ ZOLLINGER –ELLISON SYNDROME
  • ↳ Severe peptic ulcer diathesis secondary to gastric acid hypersecretion due to unregulated gastrin release from non- b cell endocrine tumor (gastrinoma) defines the components of Zollinger –Ellison syndrome.
  • ↳ Tumor Distribution: -
  • ↳ 1. 80% within gastrinoma triangle.
  • ↳ 2. Duodenal tumors constitute the most common non-pancreatic lesion.
  • ↳ 3. Lesser common sites – Stomach, bones, ovaries, heart, Liver, Lymph Nodes.
  • ↳ Clinical Manifestation:
  • ↳ 1. Most common = Peptic Ulcer (> 90%)
  • ↳ 2. Next most common – Diarrhoea
  • ↳ Gastrinomas can develop in the presence of MEN 1 syndrome.
  • ↳ Diagnosis:
  • ↳ BAO = Based acid Output
  • ↳ MAO = Acid output followed by administration of intravenous pentagastrin.
  • ↳ BAO > 15 meq/h and BAO/MAO ratio > 0.6 is highly suggestive of ZES.
  • ↳ (B) Provocative Tests
  • ↳ 1. Secretion stimulation test (Most sensitive/specific)
  • ↳ 2. Calcium infusion study
  • ↳ 3. Standard meal test
  • ↳ Secretion Stimulation Test :
  • ↳ A rise of > 200 pg/mL of serum gastrin level within 15 minutes of secretin injection confirm ZES.(Option 4 signify absolute level of serum gastrin level)

References:

  • ↳ The middle third contains both striated and smooth muscle.
  • ↳ The lower third and lower esophageal sphincter contain only smooth muscle.

questions.text: A healthy 30-year-old G1P0 at 41 weeks gestational age presents to labor and delivery at 11:00 PM because she is concerned that her baby has not been moving as much as usual for the past 24 hours. On arrival to labor and delivery, her blood pressure is initially 140/90 but decreases with rest to 120/75. She denies headache, rupture of membranes, regular uterine contractions, or vaginal bleeding. The fetal heart rate baseline is 180 beats per minute with absent variability. There are uterine contractions every 3 minutes accompanied by late fetal heart rate decelerations. The patient’s urinalysis shows no proteinuria. Which of the following is the appropriate plan of management for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Administer intravenous MgSO4 and induce labor with Pitocin.

options.label: C
options.text: Ripen cervix overnight with prostaglandin E2 (Cervidil) and proceed with Pitocin induction in the morning.

options.label: D
options.text: Admit the patient and schedule a caesarean section in the morning, after the patient has been NPO for 12 hours.

questions.correct_answer: A. Proceed with emergent caesarean section.

questions.text: A new patient presents to your office for her first prenatal visit. By her last menstrual period she is 11 weeks pregnant. This is the first pregnancy for this 36-year-old woman. She has no medical problems. At this visit you observe that her uterus is palpable midway between the pubic symphysis and the umbilicus. No fetal heart tones are audible with the Doppler stethoscope. options.label: A
options.text: Reassure her that fetal heart tones are not yet audible with the Doppler stethoscope at this gestational age.

options.label: B
options.text: Schedule genetic amniocentesis right away because of her advanced maternal age.

options.label: C
options.text: Schedule her for a dilatation and curettage because she has a molar pregnancy since her uterus is too large and the fetal heart tones are not audible.

options.label: D
options.text: Schedule an ultrasound as soon as possible to determine the gestational age and viability of the fetus.

questions.correct_answer: D. Schedule an ultrasound as soon as possible to determine the gestational age and viability of the fetus.
